content:
With the world being such a busy place, and time being something we have less of every day, home workouts are becoming more and more popular
One of the hard things about this style of training, that many people seem to struggle with, is keeping motivation high
Here’s 8 tips I found to stay motivated and keep your momentum going at home
Tip #1 - Set Clear Goals #When you know where you’re going, it’s easier to get there
With clear goals in mind, you can keep chipping away at them, until you reach where you want to be
Setting a goal like “Get fit” won’t cut it
You have to make them S.M.A.R.T.
S. Specific - Like I said before, “Get fit” won’t cut it. Make it more along the lines of “train 3 times a week to lose weight, build muscle, and see my abs”
M. Measurable - Can you measure it? Ask yourself “Can I see my abs?” No? You still have work to do
A. Attainable - It has to be something you can actually work towards. Being able to do no handed pushups for example, isn’t a thing, so don’t even go there.
R. Realistic - it’s no good saying “by tomorrow” because that won’t happen. You also can’t work towards becoming bulletproof - just keep it real
T. Time based - give yourself a realistic deadline. Even if you don’t quite reach your goal in that time frame, you’ll be a lot better than when you started
Personally, I work in 90 day sprints, then evaluate the goal
Now that you know about SMART goals, a good example would be “train 3x a week for the next 90 days so I can see my abs”
That’s actually doable and will keep you on track
Tip #2 - Create a dedicated space #Having a dedicated space really helps with motovation
You have a set area to go to when it’s time to train, kind of like going to a gym
You have everything you need right there in one place, so there’s no time wasting fetching equipment from around the house
This makes the perceived effort needed to get a training session in, much lower in your mind
You don’t need to take up an entire room either
My space takes up a doorframe and an exercise mat
You could throw in some parralettes and dip bars which could be put to one side when not being used
Whatever you have though , make sure you have easy access to it from where you train
Tip #3 - Follow a routine #It’s far easier to stay consistent when you have a set routine to follow
Take all the guess work out of it and it becomes a habit a lot easier
You know on Monday - you do a b c, Tuesday - X y z, and so on for the whole week
Once it becomes a habit, the motivation to train becomes irrelevant
You just do it
Try to stick to working out at the same time of day and treat each session as an important appointment you have with yourself
You can’t let yourself down this way
I have a rule I stick to for this:
Never miss a Monday
The rest of the week just falls into place after a Monday session
Tip #4 - Train with friends #Having a training buddy puts pressure on you to show up
You can’t let your friends down now can you?
Sometimes this can be a challenge when training at home, so joining an online community is a great idea to get around this
When you surround yourself with other people on a similar path, you enjoy talking about progress, programs and seeing what others are doing
Tip #5 - Use Technology #Apps on your phone make tracking workouts easier
Some also have communities built in
They can have structured programs for you to follow or make tracking your own a piece of low calorie cake
I use Notion for tracking progress and X for the community side of fitness
Fitness X is full of great people so come and say hello some time
Tip #6 - Mix things up #Mixing things up is a cheat code for staying motivated
Boredom provides resistance which leads to quitting
We definitely don’t want that
Although I recommend sticking to a proven program for building muscle, and burning fat, rest days are a different kettle of fish
You could go for a long walk, go swimming, take a hike up a mountain, do some jump rope, or play on the beach with some friends
Keeping things fun keeps them interesting and enjoyable
Tip #7 - Reward yourself #Rewarding yourself improves motivation on a psychological level
When you have to go shopping for new clothes because your old ones are too big, it feels great
A day at the spa for hitting a target is another great reward
Even a movie night with the family and some popcorn is a great way to reward yourself
When you have something to look forward to on top of your goals, it makes them more enjoyable
Being able to tell yourself “I earned this” gives you a great sense of accomplishment
Set up a reward system for yourself and keep the gains coming
Tip #8 - Stay Positive #This gets easier the more you train
In the beginning though, keeping a positive mental attitude will keep you going
Focus on the benefits you’re getting until you feel them kicking in
The mental health benefits of this alone make it worth while
Life happens at times, and a positive outlook will keep you on the rails
Setbacks don’t mean failure
Staying set back does
Positivity and focusing on the benefits is the key to keep you on your journey, and reach your goals
Bonus tip - Forget Motivation #Motivation just gets you started
It could be an event that happens or something somebody says
That one event isn’t enough to keep you going in the long run
You need discipline
Discipline is when you do the work, even when you don’t feel like it
You’re never going to think “man, I regret that workout”
I guarentee you think “man I regret not working out” though
Sometimes it’s unavoidable, but if you can do the work, you should do the work, no matter how you feel about it, and you know this
We all get days when our minds will tell us not to bother that day, but you must
Even if you just do one set of pushups, you’ll find that once you start, you’ll complete your workout for the day
Conclusion #So there’s my tips about staying motivated and a bonus that overrides them all
Set S. M. A. R. T Goals Create a dedicated space Follow a routine Train with friends Use Technology Mix things up Reward Yourself Stay Positive Use Discipline Try to remember: little by little, it becomes a lot
One day you’ll look back on your progress and think “wow, I did all that” and feel proud of yourself
I promise
You just have to keep pushing forwards
summary: With the world being such a busy place, and time being something we have less of every day, home workouts are becoming more and more popular
title: No Gym, No Problem: How to Stay Motivated with Home Workouts

content:
Working out at home has become a lot more popular since the pandemic
With people either being more concerned about their health, but unable to visit a gym, they had to turn to the Internet to figure out how to stay fit
This post explores how home workouts offer a convenient way to build great strength from the comfort of your own home
You see
Everybody and their nan can do a workout at home
There’s not a lot of expensive equipment needed, and you don’t even have to travel to a gym
This makes the cost of doing it accessible to everybody
There’s zero monthly membership fees and you don’t need to buy enough weight plates to sink a battle ship either
With home workouts, you are the weight!
This also saves you time, which a lot of people use as an excuse not to workout at all!
“I haven’t got time to workout, the gyms too far away”
Don’t be that guy
You don’t have to travel anywhere to do them and they can be very short if you’re pressed for time
Think about it…
How long does it take you to get off the couch and drop down to the floor to bust out some push ups?
Now compare that to getting your kit ready, travelling to the gym, doing your workout (hopefully it’s quiet so you don’t have to wait) and then travel back home again!
No ta
Plus, you get to do it no matter what time of day it is
If you prefer really early workouts… No problem
And if you don’t have time until after gym hours… You can still get a sweat on at home.
So what are the major benefits of this way of training?
Personally, I wouldn’t be exercising at all if the gym was my only option
The anxiety I would get from the thought of going there stopped me going at all
The funny thing is
Now that I train regularly at home, I could go to the gym because of the confidence I now have
Working out improved my mental health incredibly, and it still does
The regular exercise improved my ability to focus too
Theres something about feeling powerful that helps keep you motivated on work
Maybe it’s the testosterone boosting effect of muscle building
Whatever it is
Work becomes play, which helps keep you motivated and consistent
Now I’ve heard people say “but you need a gym for progressive overload”
Eeeerrrm… No you don’t!
You can easily customize your workout plan to increase the difficulty of it
I’m not just talking about doing more reps either
Let’s take push ups for an example
You can start them with your hands up high
Then lower your hands to the floor and use your knees
Then move on to raising your knees off the floor to make it harder again
This is how progressive overload works with home workouts
You don’t need weights until you’re really freaking strong, by which time you’ll be able to bust out one armed push ups with ease!
This is true with every move you can do to train your entire body
Speaking of which…
Full body workouts are much faster than gym workouts
Seeing as you train multiple muscles as a group with each movement, there’s no need for isolation moves which only work one muscle at a time
This makes them grow stronger as a unit, building functional strength
Basically, you move your body easier this way, even when a heavy load is on you
Ask my boss
He hates how I can lift a 75kg bag of potatoes on top of the fridge like it’s nothing
The fact is, it’s a highly effective way to build overall strength you use every day
It’s also an effective way to build core strength, as every single movement takes some form of balance to achieve
Your abs and stabiliser muscles get worked no matter what you’re doing, from push ups and pull ups to squats
This improves your balance too (pretty handy for a day surfing)
If you want to start doing home workouts, here’s some practical tips for you to help you get going
Create a dedicated space You don’t need a large area, but it should be the same area you use every time
Keep it clutter free and add anything to keep you motivated there
Try to do it at the same time each week If you can build a habit of working out every morning for example, you’ll get further than doing it when you feel like it
Eat carbs before working out A sugary snack like Greek yogurt, berries and honey will give you more energy to burn while you workout
Eating about 30 minutes before starting means that extra energy will be floating around your bloodstream while you train
Take progress photos Once you notice changes taking place, progress photos can really help keep you motivated
Sometimes the scales don’t move very much, even though your body has changed
Muscle weighs more than fat so progress photos are a better way to track your progress (hence the name)
So there you go
Home workouts are quicker and more convenient than gym workouts and can be done by anyone (ask your nan)
They save you money, improve your mental health, and turn you into a machine (not literally though)
I challenge you to start home workouts and let me know how you get on down below
summary: Working out at home has become a lot more popular since the pandemic
